questions.prompt: The linearity property of the FS requires that all signals have:
options: B) The same fundamental frequency ω₀
questions.explanation: Linearity says αX_k + βY_k only when x(t) and y(t) share the same ω₀. If they have different fundamental frequencies, the harmonic grids don't align and you cannot simply add coefficients at the same index k.

questions.prompt: If x(t) has FS coefficients X_k, the coefficients of x(t − t₀) are:
questions.explanation: Time shifting introduces a linear phase factor: x(t − t₀) ↔ X_k e^{−jkω₀t₀}. The minus sign in the exponent is critical. This phase factor has magnitude 1, so |X_k| is unchanged.

questions.prompt: Time shifting a signal in the FS domain changes:
options: C) Both magnitude and phase spectra
questions.explanation: The time shift factor e^{−jkω₀t₀} has |e^{−jkω₀t₀}| = 1, so multiplying X_k by it doesn't change the magnitude. Only the phase changes: ∠X_k' = ∠X_k − kω₀t₀. This is a key physical insight.

Time reversal mirrors the index: x(−t) ↔ X_{−k}. Replacing t with −t in the synthesis equation and substituting m = −k gives the result. For real signals, X_{−k} = X_k*, so time reversal also gives the conjugate.

questions.prompt: If x(t) has period T₀ and FS coefficients X_k, then x(2t) has:
questions.explanation: Time scaling by α = 2 compresses the signal: period becomes T₀/2, fundamental frequency becomes 2ω₀. But the FS coefficients X_k remain unchanged. The same magnitudes and phases, just on a faster time scale.

questions.prompt: For x(t) ↔ X_k, the FS of x(t − T₀/4) has phase shift per harmonic of:
questions.explanation: The phase shift is −kω₀t₀ = −k(2π/T₀)(T₀/4) = −kπ/2. So k=1 gets −π/2, k=2 gets −π, k=3 gets −3π/2, etc. The phase change is proportional to k — higher harmonics shift more.

questions.prompt: Why does a higher harmonic experience a larger phase change for the same time shift?
options: A) Higher harmonics have larger amplitude
B) Higher harmonics oscillate faster, so the same time shift represents more cycles
C) Higher harmonics are always imaginary
D) The 1/T₀ factor increases with k
questions.explanation: A time shift of t₀ seconds represents t₀/T_k cycles for the k-th harmonic (where T_k = T₀/k). Higher k means shorter period T_k, so the same t₀ covers more cycles → larger phase change. The phase shift is −kω₀t₀, linearly proportional to k.

questions.prompt: If x(t) = 3·p(t) + 2·q(t) where p and q have FS coefficients P_k and Q_k with the same ω₀, then X_k =
questions.explanation: By linearity: x(t) = αp(t) + βq(t) → X_k = αP_k + βQ_k = 3P_k + 2Q_k. This works because both signals share the same ω₀.

questions.prompt: For a real signal x(t), time reversal x(−t) has FS coefficients X_{−k}. Using conjugate symmetry X_{−k} = X_k*, this means:
options: A) x(−t) has the same FS as x(t)
B) The FS of x(−t) is the conjugate of the FS of x(t)
D) The FS of x(−t) has double the magnitude
questions.explanation: For real signals: X_{−k} = X_k*. So x(−t) ↔ X_{−k} = X_k*. The FS of the time-reversed signal is the complex conjugate of the original FS. This means magnitudes are identical but phases are negated.

questions.prompt: Which property would you use to find the FS of x(t) = sin(10t) + 2cos(10t) if you know the FS of sin(10t) and cos(10t)?
questions.explanation: Both sin(10t) and cos(10t) share ω₀ = 10. The signal x(t) is a linear combination (1·sin + 2·cos), so linearity applies directly: X_k = 1·(FS of sin) + 2·(FS of cos).
